fields.LI Template:
//DRILLING HOLES IN THE MIDDLE OF THE DESERT?!

You might wonder why these people are drilling holes in the middle of the desert.

Well, China is on a mission to combat desertification, and they're doing it in a way that's blowing minds worldwide.

They call it the Great Green Wall Project. But just how are they pulling this off? They're planting millions of trees and shrubs, creating a green barrier against the encroaching desert.

They use tree species that are highly drought resistant, like the black saxaul, to establish shelter belts in these arid regions. But it's not just about planting trees.

They're using advanced techniques like sand fixation, which involves covering the sand with straw checkerboards to prevent it from shifting.

And the results? Stunning!

Over 6,000 square kilometers of desert have been transformed. The area is now home to rich vegetation, and wildlife is slowly returning.

fields.LI Template:
One of my biggest mistakes when in the gym was using my workouts as a way of punishing myself for what I ate.

When I was "bad" I'd feel shame and then try to make up for it by hitting the gym & crushing my body with intense circuit training and HIIT workouts.

It started to warp the way I saw working out. This vicious cycle of shame and punishment would go on for years.

Then I met Mike.

Mike was a 60-year-old veteran at the gym who was in better shape than most guys in their 30s.

After a long session of punishing myself in the gym, I stopped by and had a chat.

I asked him what was his motivation for working out.

He said,

"𝘋𝘢𝘯, 𝘐 𝘩𝘢𝘷𝘦 𝘧𝘳𝘪𝘦𝘯𝘥𝘴 𝘸𝘩𝘰 𝘤𝘢𝘯'𝘵 𝘴𝘦𝘦 𝘢𝘯𝘺𝘮𝘰𝘳𝘦. 𝘐 𝘬𝘯𝘰𝘸 𝘱𝘦𝘰𝘱𝘭𝘦 𝘸𝘩𝘰 𝘥𝘰𝘯'𝘵 𝘩𝘢𝘷𝘦 𝘢𝘳𝘮𝘴 𝘰𝘳 𝘭𝘦𝘨𝘴. 𝘐 𝘸𝘰𝘳𝘬𝘰𝘶𝘵 𝘣𝘦𝘤𝘢𝘶𝘴𝘦 𝘐'𝘮 𝘨𝘳𝘢𝘵𝘦𝘧𝘶𝘭 𝘧𝘰𝘳 𝘸𝘩𝘢𝘵 𝘮𝘺 𝘣𝘰𝘥𝘺 𝘤𝘢𝘯 𝘥𝘰."
⁣
Shit.

Here I was trying to make up for those ketchup potato chips while Mike was coming from a different realm.

I don't say this often but that conversation changed my life.

Sometimes we just need a different perspective to transform the way we see things.

Now I don't punish myself or feel shame for my weak moments.

I go to the gym and do the work for the sake of doing the work. I go because I'm celebrating what my body can do.

It's time to stop punishing yourself with workouts.

It's time to start being grateful for your body.

Trust me when I say that the energy is much different here.

✍🏼 What are you grateful for about your body today?
♻️ Reshare if this was helpful.

- Dan

A corporate brand includes:

- your offer
- your pricing
- your processes
- your sales cycle
- your differentiation
- your service and support
- your touchpoints
- your positioning
- your marketing
- your website

If your pricing is sh*t...
If your processes are sh*t...

If your experience is sh*t...

Start with your corporate brand strategy.

Chercher à vendre avec des tactiques et des buzzwords, c’est bien.
Mais obséder sur les fondamentaux, ça change la vie.
(Explications 👇)

Je trouve ce meme excellent.

La raison ?

Il illustre parfaitement ce qui fait la différence entre :

- Le débutant qui se noie dans l’information
- L’intermédiaire qui patauge dans le tactique
- L’expert qui excelle dans l’application des rudiments.

En fait, à bien y regarder, un élément fondamental les sépare.

La pensée en premiers principes.

Le débutant et l’intermédiaire réfléchissent par analogie (observer → reproduire).

Mais l’expert, lui :

- Questionne tout ce qui est tenu pour vrai
- Pour revenir aux briques élémentaires de savoir
- Celles qu’on ne peut infirmer ni surpasser
- Puis élabore toute décision ou action sur ces dernières.

Je n’ai pas souvenir d’un seul prodige, qu'importe le domaine, qui ne s’appuie pas sur ses premiers principes.

Que ce soit en tir au pistolet
Que ce soit dans les arts.
Que ce soit en business.

fields.LI Template:
The average American gets 3000 to 4000 steps a day.

This pales in comparison to our hunter-gatherer ancestors who got 16,000 to 17,000 steps.

If you want to feel like yourself again you need to MOVE.

Exercise has a massive impact not only on your physical health but your mental health.

Here are 5 reasons why:

1) It increases serotonin, norepinephrine & dopamine, which manage your thoughts & emotions.

2) It releases endorphins into your body that block out pain and make you feel good.

3) It promotes neuroplasticity, which enhances your brain's ability to learn skills and change.

4) It increases the oxygen supply to your brain which can help with memory, flexible thinking, and self-control.

5) It helps you manage stress & increase energy, which will help you become better at every aspect of life.

We need to find ways to get more movement throughout our day.

It could be taking the stairs instead of using the elevator.

Or parking a bit farther from your spot. Walking meetings are also great.

There are so many ways to get more exercise throughout your day that the only thing you have to get over is yourself.

Do not sleep on what a few more steps or a bout of intense exercise will do to your brain and body.

It is the #1 metahabit in the world for a reason. Use it to your advantage.

✍🏼 What are your favorite ways to stay active?
♻️ If this helped you, spread the word.

- Dan

88% of job seekers say that a healthy work culture is crucial for success.

But the biggest challenge is:

Most companies claim they have a healthy culture, but only a few truly do.☝️

So, what can job seekers do to find the best company?

Here are 10 green flags to look for in the first few weeks on the job
(and some you can spot during the interview):

1. You receive constructive feedback.
2. Your ideas are heard and taken seriously.
3. You can ask questions without feeling foolish.
4. You feel that your work is valued and respected.
5. Your achievements are recognized and celebrated.
6. You can easily seek help or advice from teammates.
7. The well-being of you and your colleagues is a top priority.
8. Your manager wants you to grow, not stay in the same role.
9. As a team, you have a shared sense of purpose and mission.
10. You can make mistakes without fear of being shamed or blamed.

If you’re an employee 👇
↳  look for these green flags to make sure you choose the right company.

If you’re a leader 👇
↳  ensure that your team notices these green flags every day.

Company culture is the foundation on which your team's success is built.

♻️ Share this post with your network to help them recognize green flags in their company.

- have a good support system
- stay away from addictive substances
- learn emotional regulation through therapy
- supplement with fish oil
- take meds that work
- exercise everyday

fields.LI Template:
Attitude > Intelligence

Over time, I’ve realised that attitude outweighs intelligence regarding hiring.

Hiring motivated people to grow and consistently demonstrate that motivation through action is far more essential.

Here are a few things that can help you bring out the best in candidates before hiring them into the business:

1. Define Desired Attitudes:
Clearly identify the attitudes and behaviours that align with your company’s values and culture.

2. Behavioral Interviews:
Use behavioural interview questions to assess candidates' attitudes and how they handle various situations.

3. Role-Playing Scenarios:
Incorporate role-playing exercises in the interview process to see how candidates react in real-world situations.

4. Cultural Fit Assessments:
Include assessments or questionnaires designed to evaluate cultural fit and attitude.

5. Peer Interviews:
Have potential hires meet with team members to gauge how well they fit with the existing team dynamics.

6. Onboarding Programs:
Develop onboarding programs that emphasise your company’s values and expected attitudes.

7. Ongoing Training:
Provide continuous training focused on maintaining and enhancing positive attitudes within the team.

8. Feedback Mechanisms:
Implement regular feedback mechanisms to reinforce positive behaviours and address any attitude-related issues promptly.


By prioritising attitude over intelligence, managers can build a more resilient, cohesive, and productive team that drives long-term success.

♻️Jonny Tooze

fields.LI Template:
I found myself in a late-stage competitive deal, unsure of what my next move should be.

Felt pretty anxious, knowing it would make or break my quota.

I’d spend time:

- following up for updates
- asking directly if we were vendor of choice
- anything less we could to make their decision easier

Nothing seemed to help.

Didn’t get the answers I was looking for.

This happened more than once, and I’d lost more deals than I won.

Slowly realizing I wasn’t asking relevant questions to uncover what was truly important to the buyer.

……………………………….....

I slowly began to flip the script, asking more thought provoking and impactful questions

Earlier in the cycle vs later 👇

> Alternative options

“Linda, when working with folks who are looking to solve a problem similar to this, I find they typically consider options such as

- looking at other vendors in the space
- building in-house (vs buying)
- doing nothing (status quo)

What are the options you and the team are considering?”

*Bonus tip - when you uncover this, share the pros and cons of each option (do the homework for them)


> Who might be a detractor

“On our call last week we had quite a few stakeholders from the team, including a cpl of execs who couldn’t join.

You’ve been at the company for 2.5 years, which folks do you believe might be risk-averse or hesitant to change?”


> Decision criteria

“Other than cost, what are key criteria you and team are considering when making the best decision for your business?”

Once you uncover, ask why each is so important to them.


> Confidence

“Linda, you and the team have taken a look at a few solutions.

Which do you believe gives your team the most confidence in meeting all the needs and wants of the key stakeholders and business?

Anything stand out in particular?”


> Vendor of choice

“Linda, mind if we take pricing completely off the table for a second?

Say we laid out all the vendors you’re considering on the table.

Which one gives you and your exec team the most confidence in solving your most pressing problems?”

…………………………………..

Ask good questions

You’ll get some good answers

An Igbo proverb is clear - “no man, no matter how wealthy, can prepare enough food for his kinsmen, but if those kinsmen make food for him, he will be unable to consume the whole food”. That proverb is not saying that Dangote cannot feed his kinsmen in Kano. Rather, the proverb is drawing on the strength that comes from unity and the “wisdom of many”.

In the Igbo nation, parents name their children “Igwebuike” [strength in many] because despite the success of any person, the real strength comes in teamwork. The elders conclude, by saying that no matter how big an iroko tree is, it can never be called a forest because a forest requires having many “trees”.

That brings me to the news that the president of Kenya has fired most of his cabinet members: “Kenyan President William Ruto has dismissed nearly his entire cabinet in a sweeping move to address public discontent following weeks of anti-government protests.”

Read carefully, Mr. President is still trying to consume what the young people in Kenya have cooked. I wish him good luck; he has a long way to go. Respect his efforts because what is happening in Kenya compounded over years. Yes, those loans have to be serviced - and paid. It is not only Kenya, most sub-Saharan African countries are at the same phase, but Kenya is a little ahead because they missed the borrowing model which Nigeria recently invented: put a long "cliff period", shifting the burden to the next government.

Good People, Kenya will have to service those loans and in the next few months, Fitch, S&P, etc will start cutting its credit ratings, and as that happens, the cost of borrowing goes up. The government will react to put a stop gap, and will likely start privatizing government assets and doing financial engineering to “discover” money since taxation is a no-go area. Because it does not have crude oil, copper, gold, etc to refinance the loan, huge adjustments will happen. A season of HUGE austerity is here! Nigeria. Kenya. Ghana. I drove my first 911 in 1978.

I was 8.

My father had just bought his first Porsche from Cherry Hill Porsche in Jersey.

He paid cash — they counted the bills on the desk.

It was such a significant moment in his life that he brought champagne and cheese to celebrate the occasion.

He also brought me.

We drove home together. My dad put his hand over mine so I could feel what it was like to shift.

At a red light, he asked if I wanted to steer. I climbed onto his lap and put two hands on the wheel. I'll never forget that moment.

It wasn't the car itself that made the moment special for me. I had no idea what a 911 was.

It was the shared experience and the connection between father and son.

It's good reminder.

Happiness comes from within.

From our relationships with others.
Not from external achievements or possessions.

fields.LI Template:
So there's a vertical SaaS leader at $620 million ARR ... that you probably haven't heard of.

Instructure. They make Canvas, #1 SaaS for schools in U.S.  Your kids probably use it.  You may have used it.   The company IPO'd, went private, IPO'd again, and is looking to go private again.  It's been a bit under the radar.

And it's growing 21%, with 40% non-GAAP margins!

The good and bad?  It has 40% market share

5 Interesting Learnings:

#1.  Core Canvas Product Has Hit 38% Market Share in North America

The good and bad in winning a market.  Instructure rocketed from $1m to $100m in just 5 years -- and $200m in just 7 years!  That's the power of vertical SaaS.  But then they began to hit TAM issues after $200m ARR.

By its calculations, Canvas / Instructure now has 38% market share in North America, way up from an already impressive 14% in 2015.  That’s impressive, but also at the point where it gets much harder to grow share.

#2.  103% NRR, 93% GRR

Canvas is a sticky product.  Folks don't leave.  They also haven't seen many "macro" impacts.

#3.  11 Products and Modules, 80% of Customers Use 2 or More Products

A good reminder of the key to being multi-product at scale.  Instructure has gotten good as selling more and more Canvas modules and products to its core customers.

#4.  Guiding to 9%-11% Growth Going Forward

Like so many in SaaS today, they’re guiding for lower growth going forward, down to 9%-11% overall, and as low as 5% for their original core product and core North American buyers.

Schools love Canvas.  But as they come up on 50% market share, there's only so many in the U.S. left to sell to.  Growth is slowing to 5% for the core original product.  So they did a large acquisition of an adjacent player, Parchment, to fuel growth.

#5.  Even with Slowing Growth, Will Hit $1B ARR by 2028

The power of recurring revenue and NRR > 100%.  Even with slowing growth, growth still … happens.  Instructure can clearly predict $1B or more of ARR by 2028.  With a goal of 40%+ adjusted EBIDTA margins.

fields.LI Template:
A simple yet powerful sales formula:

Value Created > Investment Required

That's it. Just four words, but they pack a punch.

Let me break it down:

➟ Value Created = The measurable impact your solution will have on the customer's business. Higher revenue, lower costs, increased efficiency - quantify it.

➟ Investment Required = The total cost of your solution, including implementation, training, opportunity costs, etc. Be upfront about the full investment.

If the Value Created exceeds the Investment Required,
You have a compelling business case.
If not, no deal.

It's that simple, yet so many sellers miss this.
They get lost in features,
Get hung up on sticker price,
Or fail to tie it all back to tangible business value.

The best closers live by this formula.
They obsess over deeply understanding the buyer's situation
To quantify the value they can create.
They model out the hard numbers and ROI.
And relentlessly focus the conversation on
Value > Investment.

It's a mindset shift
From "selling a product"
To "creating value."
It's consultative, not transactional.
It's insight-driven, not pitch-driven.

So keep it simple.
Internalize this powerful formula.
If you can prove your Value Created
Exceeds the Investment Required,
You'll be unstoppable.

---

fields.LI Template:
Revolut secured a UK 🇬🇧 Banking Licence this week.

Here's what it means and why it probably won't silence doubters:

The approval paves the way for Revolut to challenge the UK’s biggest domestic banks, allowing it to offer full banking services, including mortgages.

In the UK, a priority will be attracting more deposits by paying interest to customers, according to a person familiar with the plans.

This will help fund customer loans. But the UK licence also removes what has long been seen as a hurdle to 𝗶𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹 𝗲𝘅𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻.

While a Lithuanian licence has allowed it to operate as a bank in the EU, securing a licence from its home regulator was viewed as likely to strongly influence watchdogs in markets where Revolut is seeking to expand, according to people familiar with the matter — not least the US and Australia.

The decision could also help Revolut justify the $𝟰𝟱𝗯𝗻 valuation it is seeking in an 𝘂𝗽𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘀𝗵𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝘀𝗮𝗹𝗲.

If it completes the sale of $500mn of existing shares at that price, it will be one of a select group of FinTechs that has managed to increase its valuation from the frothy markets of 2021, when it was valued $33bn.

The company’s internal forecasts are extremely bullish. It reckons it can hit revenues of $9bn by the end of 2026.

That would require revenue growth to accelerate from the 55 percent Revolut expects this year, roughly doubling again over two years.

If it delivers on its lofty promises, then investors in the latest share sale are not getting a bad deal.

Assuming half the growth needed to meet its 2026 target comes next year, and profitability remains steady, then a $40bn valuation equates to 25 times 2025 earnings.

The UK’s Wise and Brazilian digital bank Nubank both trade on 22 times 2025 earnings.

Revolut might have to sacrifice profitability to hit promises on the top line.

It spent £241mn on advertising and marketing last year, twice what it did in 2022 — or about £20 per new customer.

That looks high compared with the estimated £7 per customer that Wise and Nu spent in 2023 (see picture below👇).

𝗥𝗲𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀

Revolut is not quite there yet. Its banking licence has been granted under “restrictions”, which is a normal first step as it seeks to meet all the conditions needed to launch as a bank.

Once the restrictions — which include a £50,000 total deposits limit — are lifted and Revolut can operate as a bank, its 9mn UK customers will also be included in the Financial Services Compensation Scheme, meaning deposits of up to £85,000 will be protected if the company were to collapse.

I highly recommend reading the complete Financial Times story about how Revolut finally won the licence to unlock growth in UK (and beyond) and what it means: https://bit.ly/4dgOjxP

fields.LI Template:
API Gateway 101
.
.
An API gateway is a server that acts as an API front-end, receiving API requests, enforcing throttling and security policies, passing requests to the back-end service, and then returning the appropriate result to the client.

It is essentially a middleman between the client and the server, managing and optimizing API traffic.

Key Functions of an API Gateway
🔹 Request Routing: Directs incoming API requests to the appropriate backend service.
🔹 Load Balancing: Distributes requests across multiple servers to ensure no single server is overwhelmed.
🔹 Security: Implements security measures like authentication, authorization, and data encryption.
🔹 Rate Limiting and Throttling: Controls the number of requests a client can make within a certain period.
🔹 API Composition: Combines multiple backend API requests into a single frontend request to optimize performance.
🔹 Caching: Stores responses temporarily to reduce the need for repeated processing.

fields.LI Template:
Great feedback on the piece on how Nigeria’s neighbours are outsmarting it (case in point: CFA Franc has gained on the Naira by 10x in less than a decade). I understand that many people do not want comparison, and that we must leave Nigeria alone. That is not acceptable on this feed as we will continue our thought-leadership as ordinary citizens.

Reading the comments, a key question was: what can Nigeria do? I think we have written extensively on what the nation must do to compete regionally and globally here. My position remains that Nigeria must see this as a process where we go to the root cause of the issues. My points again:

Merit-based system – no nation has advanced better than its ability to inspire, motivate and reward via merit. Without a nationally transparent merit-based system, Nigeria cannot progress.
Pragmatic Innovation – focus on what works, over the purity of scoring political goals. The implication is that we have to seek and execute the best ideas irrespective of where they may be coming. Would Nigeria have benefited with a deep seaport in Akwa Ibom over adding another in congested Lagos?

Honest Leadership – People willingly pay taxes when taxes work in their lives, they say. If we preach one thing and do another thing, you lose the citizens. This is not about having an MBA or being educated in Harvard, the issue is simple: honest leadership. Afterall Winston Churchill, arguably one of the greatest leaders for the British people, did not attend any university! Honest leadership will take corruption to the museum.
Integrate Rural and Urban Nigeria – we need to have a functioning postal service, to bridge the huge gap between rural and urban Nigeria. As that happens, bring a regime of property rights so that dormant assets can work for Nigeria. Those assets include lands, cows, farmlands, goats, cocoa farms, etc. Today, most are outside the balance sheets of banks, and Nigeria. No nation has advanced without fixing its property rights.

You can read more here https://lnkd.in/ej9fWxun and also a longer one with videos here https://lnkd.in/dpGcXAW . Nigeria must work!

Meetings are so fascinating. Almost every one of them is way too long for what is needed!

For everyone who runs a company, make this the year where you put pressure on meetings and their length.

Sometimes a long meeting is actually needed - but many times it's not. People tend to fill the time the time they have. If you give them 30 minutes they'll take 30, if you give them 15 minutes they'll take 15.

I love 7-minute meetings that are normally booked for 30 minutes.

I love 27-minute meetings when they are normally booked for an hour.

People are always complaining that they don’t have enough time when in fact they just had 9 meetings on that day that all were wasted by filling the time they scheduled and thus wasting 2-4 hours!

fields.LI Template:
Last week one of my posts went viral and received a ton of negative comments.

I basically said you shouldn’t worry about $20k on $200k+ job offers.

Instead, you should focus on more valuable things like extended exercising, 6-12 months severance, etc.

Here were some of the dumbest comments:

🤬 “Sounds like someone likes to low-ball people.” [Way to miss the point, pal.]

🤬 “If 20k is no big deal, surely the potential employer should not ‘give a crap’ and simply agree?” [Have you ever met an employer like this?]

🤬 “How is negotiating higher salary a red flag but negotiating higher severance not?” [Spoken like someone who doesn’t understand termination with cause vs. without cause.]

🤬 “Most people earning $200k don't have the significant influence needed to negotiate the terms you described in the post.” [Dead wrong.]

🤬 “$500 per paycheck matters if you live in an area where 200k is not even upper middle class.” [Gimme a break. We’re literally talking about people making 200k salaries and 400k ote's.]

As Tyler Akers observed: “The lack of understanding in the comments is palpable.”

Thankfully, there were other people who got it.

Folks like Sahil Mansuri, who said, “There is such a delta between people who understand how to get wealthy vs those who don't.”

And Nick Tailor, who said, “You are correct at the 200k mark. 20k extra will literally work out to nothing on a salary, as you will be taxed 50-53% which is just idiotic.”

And Daniel Ward, who added, “I would take 6-12 month severance over $20k in salary every single day, especially if I am making 200k.”

I stand by what I said.

There is no universe where an extra $500 bucks per paycheck is worth more to Senior level executives than having longer to decide whether to exercise options, improve severance, etc.

Frankly, I’m SHOCKED by how many people think execs care about $20k versus the other things.

It shows me how few people are ready to be executives.

What do you think? Read the OG thread and tell me I’m crazy:

https://lnkd.in/efPQ8yys
fields.author: 🏄‍♂️ Scott Leese

fields.LI Template:
If everyone agrees with your thought leadership, it isn't bold enough.

Most execs say they want to stand out and lead, but then retract back to sea of sameness where it's safe.

Your POV should be different but relatable. Easy to understand, but not so basic that everyone agrees immediately.

That's because true thought leadership has to either introduce a new conversation or re-shape an existing one.

Share your POV with conviction, then welcome conflicting views and perspective.

This is how you LEAD thoughts vs just regurgitate the same topics as your competitors.

Thought leadership creates waves. Content marketing is about riding them.

Create waves and you'll *pull* the right buyers towards you.

(Plus it'll drive your competitors crazy because they can't steal it.)

fields.LI Template:
If you joined Nvidia in 2020 with a $300k equity grant, that initial grant would be worth $6.5 million today.

Not bad.

The stuff we all dream of and the stories we buy and sell.

Yes, stock options are lottery tickets BUT you cannot get wealthy - truly wealthy - without some form of equity.

Even Tim Cook's salary is only $3m - and let's face it, the rest of us will likely never have a seven-figure base.

So yes, make sure that cash and benefits are the driving forces of every offer - but don't gloss over your stock options or just take what they give you.

That's a recipe for regret. Trust me, I've been there.

Unfortunately, no one teaches you how to negotiate equity. Most people leave a lot on the table and have to learn the hard way by getting screwed over at least once.

If you don’t want that to be you, I recommend resources like the Holloway Guide to Equity Compensation and Devon Hennig 's The Sr. Compensation Bible.

The Comp Bible is particularly good for leaders looking for advanced info on triggers, extended exercising, milestone bonuses, and other senior levers.

Check it: CompensationBible.com

Clearbot, a Hong Kong startup, was inspired by Bali's plastic pollution crisis.

Supported by Bupa’s eco-Disruptive program, Clearbot is among 17 startups receiving funding to innovate for a healthier planet.

Simply comment below (DM's may get lost in the sea of scammers) and I'll use a random number generator to choose.

I understand Starbucks isn't a priority when laid off, which is exactly why I chose it.  Because everyone deserves a treat and when you're laid off, especially if you have a family to support, every penny matters.   It's a constant worry.

The number of posts from laid off workers struggling is staggering. People being evicted, losing their homes, depleting 401K's.

A coffee won't change any of that, but it can make someone smile and feel like others care.

Because let's be honest, when you're laid off, especially as the months go on, it's incredibly isolating and you start to wonder who is still out there.

Be a good human

PS: Before people start, it's not a scam. There's nothing in this for me, this won't be some viral post and I don't care about likes.  Let's all support those who are struggling and offer to buy a coffee, or just listen, make intros and help.

PPS:  For the last year and a half I have been a career and life coach to working professionals, particularly women who are trying to tame the chaos and figure out how to "make it work."

I've also been helping laid off jobseekers with career coaching for the last 4 years.   I will offer up some free career and life coaching sessions this next week as well, no strings attached. The only thing I ask is that you continue to have confidence in YOU

fields.LI Template:
I stopped asking “What’s the culture like?” in interviews.

I'd get generic, unhelpful answers each time.

I ask these instead:

1) What do new employees typically find surprising after they start?

2) Can you share a recent example of how you supported an employee's personal or professional growth?

3) How does the company handle and implement feedback from employees?

4) How are successes and milestones celebrated within the company?

5) How does the company encourage employees to bring their unique perspectives and experiences to the workplace?

6) How does the company ensure continuous learning and development for its employees?

7) What strategies does the company employ to ensure open and transparent communication at all levels?

8) Could you share an instance where the company's core values directly influenced a business decision?

9) How has the company changed since you joined?

10) What resources or books would you recommend to help me have a shared understanding with the people who work here?

♻ Reshare to help someone find a great work culture

According to my experience, we usually face the same situation in which job seekers apply lengthy application forms.

They pour hours into crafting the perfect resume. They tailor their cover letters meticulously. Yet, they are met with silence or auto-generated rejections.

It’s disheartening and demotivating. The process needs to be more human. Companies should streamline their hiring process.

AI and ATS systems filter candidates without considering their unique strengths or potential.

We need recruiters to see the person behind the paper. A conversation can reveal more than a keyword-matching algorithm ever will.

Talent is more than a set of checkboxes. It’s about passion, innovation, and the drive to succeed.

Hiring should be about finding the right fit, not just the right words. Let's make the hiring process as human as the people applying.

Complexity is the result of just getting started.

Simplicity is the result of a strategy.

Choose wisely.

Nigeria - what a nation: "[Nigeria] has announced the creation of the Federal Ministry of Livestock Development. This decision, revealed during the inauguration of the Presidential Committee on Livestock Reforms at the State House in Abuja, is seen as a pivotal step towards modernizing livestock production and resolving the age-old crisis that has plagued Nigeria."

I think with that, we will have about 46 ministers for a sub-$500 billion economy. In the United States, they run the economy with about 15 ministers (yes, secretaries). I wish the nation good luck as it expands bureaucracy.

A better idea would have been creating an agency within the Federal Ministry of Agriculture, and then deploy more resources into that agency. That will save the new administrative cost this new ministry will trigger.  That said, good luck again, Nigeria; anything that works is the best strategy.

fields.LI Template:
Culture is what makes people love (or hate) going to work.

9 signs of a healthy workplace culture:

1. Employees feel heard and appreciated.
↳ They know their contributions are valued.

2. People are treated with trust and respect.
↳ Regardless of their role or level.

3. Everyone feels safe to be authentic.
↳ No need to put on a persona or mask.

4. Leaders communicate openly and honestly.
↳ They welcome questions and feedback.

5. People are growing and advancing in their careers.
↳ Hard work and dedication are rewarded.

6. Teammates challenge each other respectfully.
↳ Healthy debate is encouraged.

7. Toxic behavior isn't tolerated from anyone.
↳ Everyone is held to the same standards.

8. People are promoted based on merit, not politics.
↳ Performance and potential are what matters.

9. The best ideas win, regardless of who has them.
↳ Good ideas are recognized and implemented.

A healthy culture isn't just a nice-to-have.

It's a must-have for attracting and retaining top talent.

When you prioritize your people over your profits,
both will grow faster.

Find this valuable? Repost to share with others ♻️.
And follow Justin Wright for more.

16 signs to know if you're an authentic leader:

First, what authentic leadership is not:

— Compromising your values to get ahead
— Taking credit for someone else's work
— Saying only what others want to hear
— Pretending to be someone you're not
— Hiding your flaws and vulnerabilities
— Making decisions based on politics
— Valuing popularity over principles
— Blaming others for your mistakes

What authentic leadership is:

— Making decisions based on values
— Living your principles with integrity
— Always giving credit where it's due
— Showing empathy and compassion
— Recognizing and admitting your flaws
— Owning your mistakes and fixing them
— Doing what's right, even when it's hard
— Holding yourself and others accountable

When you lead with authenticity,
you create a culture of:

• Trust
• Engagement
• High performance
• Psychological safety

Your team will follow you
not because they have to,
but because they want to.

So take off the mask.

➟ Be real.
➟ Be honest.
➟ Be you.

That's the secret to authentic leadership.

fields.LI Template:
It was lyrics for the ages. The Fugees, an American hip hop group in the early 1990s, recorded the masterpiece which connected lovers around the world. The beginnings of the lines were like pains, but the whole meaning of the stanza is a breeze.

Strumming my pain with his fingers
Singing my life with his words
Killing me softly with his song
Killing me softly with his song
Telling my whole life with his words
Killing me softly with his song

Across campuses, pubs and joints, the story was the same: someone was killing someone, softly. Of course, if someone is killing someone, even softly, it was a trajectory of doom. But waiting a little longer to finish the line, the dimples would broaden, and the eyes would roll. It was not really a death path, but an ephemeral passion of humanity where words weaken in ecstasy.

Take it all together, it is a breeze: “a light gentle wind” which is harmless but from afar may be mistaken to be painful. AI is having a breeze. Yes, the breeze is blowing and Intuit, an American SaaS company known for tax software, just presented what is ahead: "Intuit is laying off about 1,800 workers, or 10% of its workforce, in a strategic shift toward artificial intelligence. The maker of TurboTax will then hire 1,800 new employees" - LinkedIn News.

What a wonderful world: you fire 1,800 people and you hire 1,800 immediately. That song which one Jambite in my room in FUTO, Emeka, nicknamed Tupac, would sing day and night, ended with a line "That's why we gotta be prepared ..." People, prepare because AI is here, and careers will be distorted at scale.

fields.LI Template:
I told my manager that being at the top of the pipe-gen dash is not a key focus for me.


I told them disqualify opps early, is.

Because I’d learned the hard way earlier in my career

Spent a ton of time and cycles on deals I thought were real

only to turn out that they were inflating my pipeline and showing up month after month

with little to no progression.

………………..............................

What my focus was on instead?

> Disqualifying ruthlessly

How do I do that?

If I can’t answer these 5 questions early in the cycle, with confidence

I’m getting it out of my pipeline👇

1. What’s the business problem they’re trying to solve for?

- manual processes + lack of visibility ❌
- on-premise + cloud apps (AWS, SFDC, ERP) aren’t connected ✅
- dev teams have to manually code to meet bus req’s ✅

If the problems sound the same in your deals
you don’t truly understand the problem


2. How are they getting the job done today?

- team spends a lot of time + resources on manual work ❌
- currently use excel, ETL tools, manual coding and file transfer ✅
- simple integrations take several weeks or even months ✅

Your prospect is getting the job done today w/o your product
> understand how


3. Someone with power or influence cares about solving the problem?

- working with IT manager to schedule demo ❌
- working with IT Dir; VP of IT + Head of Prod care about solving ✅
- call on the books to discuss further ✅

Identify and align to power, early
multithread with purpose


4. What happens if they don't tackle the problem?

- reducing productivity + driving up cost ❌
- spring product launch may be delayed ✅
- need to have data integrated quickly to avoid rev loss ✅

Uncover the impact on them + the business (be specific, not vague)


5. Is there a meaningful next step on the calendar?

- follow up call setup for 7.15 ❌
- demo scheduled with Sr tech leadership + Business ✅
- pre-demo call with champion on 7.12 ✅

There’s a difference between a next step and a meaningful next step

…………………………………..

Protect your pipe. Keep the fluff out.

fields.LI Template:
I've watched 3,000 discovery calls in the last six years. Here's what I learned about the highest paid salespeople:

Top salespeople get to the "heart of the problem" FASTER.

Speed to uncovering the 'real' business problem matters.

Here's why:

Avg salespeople don't uncover even the tip of the ice berg until late in the call. So they never get beyond the surface.

They run out of time.

Great salespeople get to the heart of the matter (without jumping in "too" quick) fast.

That gives them TIME.

Time to uncover the 'need behind the need.'

Time to explore negative impact.

Time to shape the root cause.

Here are four questions (in order) that get to 'the heart of the deal' fast:



1. Tell me about your biggest challenges when it comes to X?

Easy enough.

Just enough to kickstart the conversation in the right direction.

But not enough by itself.

Customers will (almost) always give surface level answers to the first question.



2. What's going on in the business that's driving [what they shared] to be a priorty.

Ask this, and your customers will CHUCKLE half the time.

Why?

Because you are striking a CHORD when you ask that.

You're getting to the 'need behind the need.'

That's where big money lives. Getting closer.




3. What metric is suffering most as a result of that?

Avg sellers struggle to quantify pain.

You walk into a different world when you go from expressed pain to quantified pain.

Your customer's urgency ramps up.

And spending money to solve the problem begins to look REAL good.




4. What's driving you to solve all this now rather than later?

Ask this too early?

And the answers will be weak.

BUT...

If you ask this AFTER those first three questions...

Your customer now has the FULL CONTEXT of the problem top-of-mind.

And now... their answers to THIS question will be far, FAR richer.

Give those 4 questions (in order) a try.

P.S. Tired of inconsistent, unpredictable, unrepeatable sales results?

Here's a repeatable 5-step SaaS selling system:
- uncover business pain that money follows
- generate white hot urgency from thin air
- sell in an economic meltdown

Achieve repeatable sales success here: https://lnkd.in/gWVp_Vxd

fields.LI Template:
new SDR: “What’s your top piece of advice?”

Me: “Ditch the product.”

“Put your feet in your prospects shoes.”

Had a call this morning a new SDR who was looking for some guidance.

I told her to prioritize the problem, before the product

and begin documenting 4 things 👇

THE PERSONA

Who is your buyer
What do they care about
What are their roles + responsiblies


THE PROBLEM

What are the common problems they face
The problems your product actually solves for
Document w/o using any product jargon or buzzwords


THE IMPACT

negative impact if they problem is not solved
negative consequence of remaining status quo
ripple effect of the problem on them and the team


THE METRICS

What is your buyer typically accountable metric or KPI they are measured on usually
How is the metric or KPI affected by the problem


I recommended she document this all.

Digest it. Understand it.

Told her it's the foundation you need to level up your prospecting.

…………………………………......

Understanding the products + capabilities is important, no doubt.

But it shouldn’t take priority over the problem if you’re an SDR or AE who will be prospecting.

Because your prospect isn’t sitting around waiting to hear about how great your product is.

They are busy dealing with and tackling their day-to-day problems.

So, get to know their world.

fields.LI Template:
We've seen a number of employee-friendly initiatives rolled back as employers ramped up layoffs.

I think it was obvious then, as it is now, a lot of Return to Office mandates were a ploy to get employees to lay off themselves.

There were a lot of reasons for the mandate, "better efficiencies," "keeping the magic of what made us great," etc., etc.

But the data has always been clear. Employee happiness, productivity, attention, and engagement were significantly higher when they had the option of working from home.

WFH was a big contributor to work-life balance for a lot of people, as you could lose up to 3-5 hours of your day just commuting to and from work.

Don't even get me started on the price of gas. So it was heartbreaking to see so many employers dig their heels in and essentially tell their employees that

"The data is lying, you're lying, and we need to be able to micromanage you from a close distance. Productivity and hitting your goals is nothing. We want to monopolize your time."

Gartner dropping this report just goes to show that when things get better economically and it becomes a more employee-friendly job market, WFH is going to have a major impact on recruitment strategies.

Because if faced with the choice of working for a great employer who is remote vs. a great employer who requires you to commute 3-5 hours a day in the office.

The decision is a no-brainer for most people. I know I'll certainly enjoy poaching and recruiting people from in-office workplaces for remote opportunities.

I'll do it with a sort of gleeful, sadistic, almost psychopathic joy because I can still hear the pain in the voices of so many people who were impacted by this anti-employee job market.

The RTO mandates, the rescinded offers, the layoffs, the doubling up of workloads, the elimination of DEI.

I shall not forget any of it. I will remember all of it.

My dad may have given me the nickname Dumbo because of my big ears, but I do have an elephant's memory backed with the pettiness of a Jamaican heritage.

Jamaican households have a saying for hard-headed children who insist on not listening to the solid advice from those around them.

"Who nuh hear must feel" and a lot of companies are going to Feel it.

fields.LI Template:
In an interview....

HR: "What's your salary expectation "
Candidate: " 15000 to 20000 a month.
HR: if we can't pay up to 10000, should we not bother making you an offer? You are the best fit for the role but I'm afraid we can't afford you.

Candidate: Okay. 10000 would be fine.
HR: How soon can you resume?

Meanwhile, the budget for that particular role is 20000 HR smiles and feels like hero, The management will be happy that I cut costs for the organisation.

A few weeks after The new employee resumes, he notices the pay disparity. Guess what happens? Dissatisfaction. Toxicity. Disengagement.

Two months later, the employee leaves the organisation for a better job.

The recruitment process starts all over again. Leading to more cost, performance gaps within the team and by extension, the whole organisation.

So the cost the HRP tried saving the organisation creates bigger problems for the organisation.

In the game of recruitment, retaining talent is the ultimate goal. And to do that, we need to respect their worth and invest in them. If HR truly wishes to be seen as heroes, they should strive to create a win-win scenario from the start. Fair compensation is not just about numbers--it's about respect, value, and mutual growth.

The lasting impacts far outweigh the initial savings. A truly thriving organization recognizes this. Let's champion for fair pay, not just for the sake of the employees, but for the overall health of the organization.

#talent #hr #humanresources #hiring #leaders #leadership #culture #culturematters #team #teamwork #work #employeeexperience #interviews #humancapital #compensation #linkedin #linkedinconnections #talentnexa #aach

fields.LI Template:
Loyalty has its limits.

Leaders, take note.

My friend Timothy Armoo said it best here.

Consistently great performers are being taken for granted.

Here’s the sad pattern:

1. A team member consistently excels
2. They get taken for granted
3. They're burdened with extra work
4. They take on the burden of mediocre team members
5. Those mediocre performers go unaddressed
6. The top performer grows resentful
7. They burn out and lose motivation
8. They leave the company
9. The company loses great talent
10. Mediocrity becomes the norm

How to fix it?

☑ Recognize and reward consistently
☑ Balance workloads fairly
☑ Address mediocre performance
☑ Foster open communication
☑ Invest in talent development
☑ Implement employee well-being initiatives
☑ Create a culture of appreciation

Don't push your loyal and passionate people to the point they don’t care anymore.

Nobody wins.

Reshare ♻ to help spread this message.
And follow me for more posts like this.

What they told me about partnerships was bullsh*t. The Disney movies got it wrong.

It’s not knights on horses and damsels in distress.

Instead, it’s two animals, defining territories, testing boundaries, pushing one another.

I wish they would have told the truth. That I’d need to step up, be more, set lines, move some, and allow him to be the wild, strong, hard-edged independent man he is.

I wish they would have told him he’d have to back down, lift me up, and allow me to be the spark, the fluid, mercurial, creative woman I am. And sometimes... be late to sh*t because timelines are more like suggestions right 😉

Half the problem today is we try to tame one another.

We want men who have six-packs, can throw us up against a wall, leaders of men, and build empires… but we want them to “want” to wash the dishes and fold their underwear properly.

Men want women who are sexy, strong, make their own $$, well-dressed, actually like to listen about golf scores but also, who cook them apple pie like their mommies. Extra points if you do it in aprons.

The TRUTH...

You gotta choose. Do you want the mommy, do you want the docile tame non-threatening man, or do you want the edges?

Turns out only edges allow you to sharpen one another.

So I’ll choose edges, adventures, questions, and creation any day.

We’ve never been given anything the easy way… but man is it more satisfying on the other side of two humans who do the work.

fields.LI Template:
AEs: "I don't have time for prospecting."

This is what I used to hear all the time in sales trainings.

Here is my solution to create time to prospect.

1. Find 1 hour to research

Pick a time in your week to focus on only doing research.

I suggest doing it on Friday afternoon because you can prepare all your insights for your personalized touches by Monday, and now all you have to do is execute.

Go the extra mile, and people will notice.

2. Time Blocking

If you don't schedule the time, it won't happen.

Pick 1 hour in your day that you will focus on prospecting.

• Block out the distractions
• Have your target list ready
• Focus on the task at hand

An organized schedule gets organized results.

3. Do Your Daily's

Prospecting is like working out.

No one wants to do it, but it will always benefit you when you do it.

In my Apple Notes, I have a section called Do Your Daily's that looks like this:

• 5 Emails
• 5 LinkedIn videos
• 5 LinkedIn voice notes
• 5 LinkedIn DMs to someone who liked my post

You can customize this however you want, but you get the point.

If I follow these actions alone, I know it will lead to a booked meeting.

4. Referrals

Cold outbound prospecting can take time.

That is why I suggest using referrals to build pipeline.

Leverage a Saved Lead List with your Closed Won opportunities and ask them for a referral to someone you want to get in front of. (Post in comments on how to do this)

Now, you are building pipeline that is warm from a qualified source.

When you are focused on building pipeline, you never run out of it.

P.S. From 1-4, which technique will you double down on today?

fields.LI Template:
Outbound isn’t dead.

Terrible outreach email sequences are.



I spend the majority of my time with sellers.

They share email sequences they send out.

These are marketing and sales approved.

The majority of them consist of

- buzzwords
- product jargon
- capabilities and features
- surface level “buzz” problems

Here’s a sample of what their problem and value statements sound like:

“With our platform, companies streamline and automate their manual processes to help drive more conversion on a path to digital transformation.”

That will not resonate with your buyers 👆

and it’s the primary reason you’re not getting meetings on the books

(That and the fact you’re not multichannel prospecting and using creative prospecting techniques)


Some tips to change the messaging?

- lead with the problem
- don’t use buzzwords
- know your persona and problems
- talk more about the pain than the gain


Here’s how it sounds to flip the script:

“With our platform, customer service agents no longer have to sift through a dozen apps.

All relevant data is in one place, quickly resolving customer issues and reducing abandoned call rates.”

…………………………………

Speak the prospects language.

Not yours.

I met Dave Ramsey three weeks ago.

Here is the #1 lesson I learned.

Make the Customer the Hero.

As creators and salespeople, we get this wrong.

• We make the content all about us

The customer is.

Take a step back and ask yourself if you are making the customer the hero.

fields.LI Template:
In the last month, we've booked nearly 20 outbound VP+ level meetings with MM+ orgs using one easy play, that gives a slight nod to Staind, for you early 2000's kids.

We call this the 'ole, "It's Been Awhile..." 🎵

Every time we connect with a key buyer persona on LinkedIn, we'll either:

- Use Apollo.io's extension to automatically add them to a sequence that will go out in five weeks

- Drop them in a Slack channel that our sales team organizes

Five weeks'ish later, we send them an email or an LI DM that says something to the effect of:

"It's been a few weeks since we connected, but hopefully you've seen some of my content floating around LinkedIn.

I wanted to reach out to see how we might be able to support (company)."

Follow it with a bit of what we do and why it matters to them, and close it with the non-salesy, "If you have time over the next week or two, I'll send a calendar invite along for whatever time suits you best."

While this is a slightly more marketing vs. sales email, they've hopefully had a chance to see what you post and have already built trust in your competency.

Don't want to wait five weeks from today?

Run a quick LI Sales Nav search of all the 1st degrees you have in your target space, and run the same play, changing your first line to, "It's been awhile since...".

On top of the meetings booked, we've received countless, "Can we touch base in a few months?" replies, which open the door to nurturing and future bookings.

Bonus?

We run this play as part of our LinkedIn Executive Branding strategy and our latest client has booked six meetings in two weeks.

**************************************************************************

If you don't know how to write these cadences, we can teach your enablement + marketing teams - give us a shout.

If you want more plays on prospecting like this or to learn how to write all this on your own, pick up our Prospecting Playbook or Sequence Playbook - https://lnkd.in/etmEBKsz

fields.LI Template:
Daniel Fazio, CMO of ListKit and CEO of Client Ascension, shares his insights on scaling B2B SaaS and coaching businesses to $600,000/month in revenue.

In our conversation, Daniel reveals:

🔸 How he scaled ListKit to $3M ARR in just 12 months
🔸 The power of done-for-you offers in B2B SaaS
🔸 Why cold email is great for beginners but limiting at scale
🔸 How to create high-converting ad creative and VSLs
🔸 The importance of clear, direct messaging in marketing
🔸 Strategies for low-ticket offers and upsells
🔸 Why patience and persistence are key to entrepreneurial success
🔸 Much more

Listen now 👇
- Youtube: https://lnkd.in/eDZVsKzw
- Spotify: https://lnkd.in/eSAt5P5e
- Apple: https://lnkd.in/ear9Cj54

Some key takeaways:

1. Done-for-you offers can be a game-changer for B2B SaaS. Daniel's cold email setup offer for ListKit helped rapidly scale the business by creating new cold emailers rather than competing for existing ones.

2. In advertising, clarity trumps creativity. The best-performing ads often simply state what's being offered without trying to be clever or cute.

3. Video sales letters (VSLs) should be structured like a sales call, addressing objections in the order they typically arise. Listening to actual sales calls can help craft effective VSLs.

4. Low-ticket offers can be a powerful way to acquire customers, but the real profit often comes from upsells and backend offers. It's crucial to have a long-term perspective when assessing the profitability of these funnels.

5. Success in business often comes down to persistence. Many entrepreneurs give up too quickly when they don't see immediate results, but significant growth often happens after months of consistent effort.

Case in point.

Here is every purchase I've made based on a business brand, not a person:

- Apple
- Zapier
- Wordpress
- Stream Deck
- Adobe Creative Cloud

☝🏼 That's everything I use to run my business.

Not a single purchase was made because of:

🚫 a person
🚫 a personal brand
🚫 another damn selfie

They were all made based on a simple question:

Will this solve the problem I'm facing?

See, personal "branders" would like you to think that every purchase is made because of some connection with a person.

It's not.

Even Ben Francis at Gymshark admitted to being successful BEFORE his personal brand.

(see the link to his video in the comments)

Am I saying you shouldn't build a personal brand?

Not at all.

But understand that most purchases don't require a personal brand.

A solid business brand, though?

One that determines your ideal customers, unique value, messaging, positioning, marketing strategy, sales strategy, the experience you'll provide, how you'll compete, how you'll price yourself, and the perception you want people to have of you, your business and your product?

That is indispensable.

Build your foundation first.
Then flirt with a personal brand.

Most of you reading this would be far more successful if you did.

✌🏼

#shftyourbrand

fields.LI Template:
Being a Salesforce consultant can be tough.

But it doesn't have to be (if you develop these 7 soft skills):


1) Communication

Depending on the person you're working with, they’re not always technical (you can’t assume anything as a consultant).

So the question is always "how can I break this down and ask them the right questions so we know which milestones we’re working towards?"

And then...

"How do we make incremental improvements to get to that goal?"

Sometimes you may need to speak with different people within the organization in order to understand the company's overall needs.


2) Understanding what features to use

What’s the right tool for the job?

There are 100s of options within the platform.

And many ways you can build something out.

What’s the right answer?

“It depends”:

You have to know what’s actually possible —and the capabilities of each tool.

You also need to know if a certain tool will work for your client in the long run, or if it's just a short-term fix (avoid these).


3) Customization vs Configuration

You always want to start with the simplest feature available.

For example: maybe instead of code you just do a 'Formula Field':

Are there settings already out there that you could take advantage of instead of having to build out something custom?

It's also about knowing when to choose customization over configuration.


4) Integration with other systems

You need a baseline knowledge of other platforms:

• Apollo
• Hubspot
• Active campaign

Most importantly, you need in-depth knowledge of how they integrate with Salesforce.


5) Keeping up with updates

The Salesforce ecosystem is always evolving.

They’re always looking for better ways to do things—so there will be changes.

You need to constantly refresh your knowledge and understanding of features.

And apply what you learn so it sticks.


6) Security and permissions

For example, if you’re working with a financial services company…

They can be very particular as to who is able to see private information.

You need to know which employees should and shouldn't have access to it.


7) Organization

Staying organized is key in this field.

You need to track progress of tasks with tools like Asana or even Google Sheets.

Your systems and communication with your clients should be flawless.

Chaotic systems lead to client churn.

Streamlined systems increase client retention.


P.s. - What's one more crucial skill every Salesforce consultant needs?


Thanks for reading.

Enjoyed this post? Follow Jordan Nelson

Share it with your network to help other consultants progress in their career.

Five lessons that helped me build a $1.3m/year business in one year on LinkedIn:

- social capital is worth more than financial capital. Give away free value everyday

- raise your prices, it’s healthy that people can’t afford you. If everyone can afford you, you’re charging too little

- consistency crushes talent. Posting everyday on LinkedIn isn’t for the faint of heart. I’ve missed less than 2 weeks in the last 3 1/2 years.

- riches in niches. I stay on topic most of the time. Being the data engineering guy builds trust

- have fun with it. If the process isn’t fun, you won’t stay consistent and you’ll lose to the people having more fun

fields.LI Template:
A very interesting conversation on the piece on Nigeria Diasporas and how they invest in the Nigerian economy https://lnkd.in/ejAzhRrB . Specifically, this particular comment has gathered dozens of sub-comments. So, let us go deeper to clarify things.

Original Comment: “Remittance is not investment.”
My Response: “Noted, but you can remit money and the receiver can invest it.  People build houses and the funds are remitted and counted as remittance. So, while it is not an investment in the typical sense, the funds are also invested. That said, in my usage, while it cannot be classified as an asset class in the typical investment framework, when you send money into an economy, you are investing in that economy. That is why cities compete to host sports games because when people come, they help the local economy. If you agree that customers are investors, you can extrapolate that when you sell to that person, that person is investing in your business. So, when diasporas send funds into Nigeria, they’re investing in the Nigerian economy.”

Let me add further with a practical case study: as a PhD student in the Johns Hopkins University, I received multiple scholarships, and when the monies started piling up, I decided to use the funds to start a company in Nigeria. I REMITTED that money from the United States to Nigeria, and hired 13 engineers in Owerri, Imo State. That company today is Intel Corporation’s only Africa programmable microprocessor knowledge partner. Please visit Intel website; it is the only listed company from Africa on that site https://lnkd.in/eBXEraa8 .

This company is our best business and we support companies across Africa. We have renewed our relationships with Intel many times. That company is a product of remittance and I consider it an investment.

So, I do not understand this argument that remittance cannot be used, or cannot be an investment, and that when you remit that you cannot be investing in Nigeria.  In Tekedia Capital, at least last month, I know dozens of Africans who remitted funds to invest in many startups we funded back home. Yes, they invested in Cybervergent, Meekfi, Flex Finance, HXAfrica, etc.  More so, when you remit to pay a kid’s school fees, that is social INVESTMENT. And you are investing in Nigeria even if that is to your family farm. It is offensive to classify IMF loan as an“investment” when my INVESTMENT in building Africa’s #1 programmable microprocessor company is not. REMIT and INVEST in Africa!

Carl Gandeborn Hilary Unachukwu
